info.title: Natural Language Understanding
info.description:
Analyze various features of text content at scale using Machine Learning and AI. Provide text, raw HTML, or a public URL and IBM Watson Natural Language Understanding will give you results for the features you request. The service cleans HTML content before analysis by default, so the results can ignore most advertisements and other unwanted content.

You can create [custom models](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing) with Watson Knowledge Studio to detect custom entities and relations in Natural Language Understanding.

externalDocs.description: For more information about this service, see the docs.

get.description:
Analyzes raw text, HTML, or a public webpage.

If a language for the input text is not specified with the `language` parameter, the service [automatically detects the language](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-detectable-languages).

x-ibm-change-notices.description: The advanced rules feature is removed. As of 24 June 2021, you can no longer run advanced rules models for Natural Language Understanding.

source: curl -u "apikey:{apikey}" \
"{url}/v1/analyze}?version=2022-04-07&url=www.ibm.com&features=keywords,entities&entities.emotion=true&entities.sentiment=true&keywords.emotion=true&keywords.sentiment=true"

post.description:
Analyzes text, HTML, or a public webpage for the following features:
- Categories
- Classifications
- Concepts
- Emotion
- Entities
- Keywords
- Metadata
- Relations
- Semantic roles
- Sentiment
- Syntax
- Summarization (Experimental)

If a language for the input text is not specified with the `language` parameter, the service [automatically detects the language](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-detectable-languages).

requestBody.description: An object containing request parameters. The `features` object and one of the `text`, `html`, or `url` attributes are required.

source: curl -X POST -u "apikey:{apikey}" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d @parameters.json "{url}/v1/analyze?version=2022-04-07"

import json
from ibm_watson import NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1
from ibm_cloud_sdk_core.authenticators import IAMAuthenticator
from ibm_watson.natural_language_understanding_v1 \ 
    import Features, EntitiesOptions, KeywordsOptions

authenticator = IAMAuthenticator('{apikey}')
natural_language_understanding = NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1(
    version='2022-04-07',
    authenticator=authenticator)

natural_language_understanding.set_service_url('{url}')

response = natural_language_understanding.analyze(
    text='IBM is an American multinational technology company '
    'headquartered in Armonk, New York, United States, '
    'with operations in over 170 countries.',
    features=Features(
        entities=EntitiesOptions(emotion=True, sentiment=True, limit=2),
        keywords=KeywordsOptions(emotion=True, sentiment=True,
                                 limit=2))).get_result()

print(json.dumps(response, indent=2))

get.description: Lists Watson Knowledge Studio [custom entities and relations models](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing) that are deployed to your Natural Language Understanding service.

source: curl -u "apikey:{apikey}" "{url}/v1/models?version=2022-04-07"

import json
from ibm_watson import NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1
from ibm_cloud_sdk_core.authenticators import IAMAuthenticator

authenticator = IAMAuthenticator('{apikey}')
natural_language_understanding = NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1(
    version='2022-04-07',
    authenticator=authenticator)

natural_language_understanding.set_service_url('{url}')

response = natural_language_understanding.list_models().get_result()

print(json.dumps(response, indent=2))

parameters.name: model_id
parameters.description: Model ID of the model to delete

source: curl -X DELETE -u "apikey:{apikey}" "{url}/v1/models/{model_id}?version=2022-04-07"

import json
from ibm_watson import NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1
from ibm_cloud_sdk_core.authenticators import IAMAuthenticator

authenticator = IAMAuthenticator('{apikey}')
natural_language_understanding = NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1(
    version='2022-04-07',
    authenticator=authenticator)

natural_language_understanding.set_service_url('{url}')

response = natural_language_understanding.delete_model(
    model_id='model_id').get_result()

print(json.dumps(response, indent=2))

post.description: (Beta) Creates a custom categories model by uploading training data and associated metadata. The model begins the training and deploying process and is ready to use when the `status` is `available`.

source:
curl -X POST -u "apikey:{apikey}" \
-H "Content-Type: multipart/form-data" \
-F "training_data=@categories_data.json;type=application/json" \
-F "language=en" \
-F "name=MyCategoriesModel" \
-F "model_version=1.0.1" \
"{url}/v1/models/categories?version=2022-04-07"

from os.path import join, dirname
from ibm_watson import NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1
from ibm_cloud_sdk_core.authenticators import IAMAuthenticator

authenticator = IAMAuthenticator('{apikey}')
natural_language_understanding = NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1(
    version='2022-04-07',
    authenticator=authenticator
)

natural_language_understanding.set_service_url('{url}')

with open(join(dirname(__file__), './.', 'categories_data.json'),
               'rb') as file:
    model=natural_language_understanding.create_categories_model(
        language='en',
        training_data=file
        name='MyCategoriesModel',
        model_version='1.0.1',
    ).get_result()
    print(json.dumps(model, indent=2))

get.description: (Beta) Returns all custom categories models associated with this service instance.

source: curl -u "apikey:{apikey}" \
"{url}/v1/models/categories?version=2022-04-07"

import json
from ibm_watson import NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1
from ibm_cloud_sdk_core.authenticators import IAMAuthenticator

authenticator = IAMAuthenticator('{apikey}')
natural_language_understanding = NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1(
    version='2022-04-07',

natural_language_understanding.set_service_url('{url}')

models = natural_language_understanding.list_categories_models().get_result()

print(json.dumps(models, indent=2))

get.description: (Beta) Returns the status of the categories model with the given model ID.

source: curl -u "apikey:{apikey}" \
"{url}/v1/models/categories/{model_id}?version=2022-04-07"

import json
from ibm_watson import NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1
from ibm_cloud_sdk_core.authenticators import IAMAuthenticator

authenticator = IAMAuthenticator('{apikey}')
natural_language_understanding = NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1(
    version='2022-04-07',
    authenticator=authenticator)

natural_language_understanding.set_service_url('{url}')

model = natural_language_understanding.get_categories_model(
  model_id='{model_id}',
).get_result()


print(json.dumps(model, indent=2))

put.description: (Beta) Overwrites the training data associated with this custom categories model and retrains the model. The new model replaces the current deployment.

source:
curl -X PUT -u "apikey:{apikey}" \
-H "Content-Type: multipart/form-data" \
-F "training_data=@categories_model.json;type=application/json" \
-F "language=en" \
-F "name=MyCategoriesModel" \
-F "description=My updated categories model" \
-F "model_version=1.0.1" \
-F "version_description=Updated version" \
"{url}/v1/models/categories/{model_id}?version=2022-04-07"

from os.path import join, dirname
from ibm_watson import NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1
from ibm_cloud_sdk_core.authenticators import IAMAuthenticator

authenticator = IAMAuthenticator('{apikey}')
natural_language_understanding = NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1(
    version='2022-04-07',
    authenticator=authenticator
)

natural_language_understanding.set_service_url('{url}')

with open(join(dirname(__file__), './.', 'categories_model.json'),
               'rb') as file:
    model=natural_language_understanding.update_categories_model(
        language='en',
        training_data=file
        name='MyCategoriesModel',
        description='My updated categories model',
        model_version='1.0.1',
        version_description='Updated version',
        model_id='{model_id}'
    ).get_result()
    print(json.dumps(model, indent=2))

delete.description: (Beta) Un-deploys the custom categories model with the given model ID and deletes all associated customer data, including any training data or binary artifacts.

source: curl -X DELETE -u "apikey:{apikey}" \
"{url}/v1/models/categories/{model_id}?version=2022-04-07"

import json
from ibm_watson import NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1
from ibm_cloud_sdk_core.authenticators import IAMAuthenticator

authenticator = IAMAuthenticator('{apikey}')
natural_language_understanding = NaturalLanguageUnderstandingV1(
    version='2022-04-07',
    authenticator=authenticator)

natural_language_understanding.set_service_url('{url}')

model = natural_language_understanding.delete_categories_model(
  model_id='{model_id}',
).get_result()


print(json.dumps(model, indent=2))

version.name: version
version.description: Release date of the API version you want to use. Specify dates in YYYY-MM-DD format. The current version is `2022-04-07`.

text.name: text
text.description: URL-encoded text to analyze. One of the `text`, `html`, or `url` parameters is required.

html.name: html
html.description: URL-encoded HTML to analyze. One of the `text`, `html`, or `url` parameters is required.

url.name: url
url.description: Public webpage to analyze. One of the `text`, `html`, or `url` parameters is required. `url` is not supported in IBM Cloud Dedicated instances.

language.name: language
language.description: ISO 639-1 code that specifies the language of your text. This overrides automatic language detection. Language support differs depending on the features you include in your analysis. For more information, see [Language support](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-language-support).

limit_text_characters.name: limit_text_characters
limit_text_characters.description: Sets the maximum number of characters that are processed by the service.

features.name: features
features.description: Comma separated list of analysis features

clean.name: clean
clean.description: Set this to `false` to disable text cleaning when analyzing webpages. For more information about webpage cleaning, see [Analyzing webpages](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-analyzing-webpages).

xpath.name: xpath
xpath.description: An [XPath query](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-analyzing-webpages#xpath) to perform on `html` or `url` input. Results of the query will be appended to the cleaned webpage text before it is analyzed. To analyze only the results of the XPath query, set the `clean` parameter to `false`.

fallback_to_raw.name: fallback_to_raw
fallback_to_raw.description: Whether to use raw HTML content if text cleaning fails

return_analyzed_text.name: return_analyzed_text
return_analyzed_text.description: Set this to `true` to show the analyzed text in the response

advanced_rules.model.name: advanced_rules.model
advanced_rules.model.description:
The advanced rules feature is deprecated. Existing models are supported until 24 June 2021, but after 10 June 2021, you will not be able to deploy advanced rules models to Natural Language Understanding. After 24 June 2021, advanced rules models will not run in Natural Language Understanding.

An advanced rules model ID

categories.explanation.name: categories.explanation
categories.explanation.description: Set this to `true` to return explanations for each categorization. **This feature is available only for English language text.**

categories.limit.name: categories.limit
categories.limit.description: Maximum number of categories to return.

categories.model.name: categories.model
categories.model.description: (Beta) Enter a [custom model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing) ID to override the standard categories model. **This feature is available only for English language text.**

classifications.model.name: classifications.model
classifications.model.description: Model ID of the classifications model to be used

concepts.limit.name: concepts.limit
concepts.limit.description: Maximum number of concepts to return.

emotion.document.name: emotion.document
emotion.document.description: Set this to `false` to hide document-level emotion results

emotion.targets.name: emotion.targets
emotion.targets.description: Target strings, separated by commas. Emotion results will be returned for each target string found in the document

entities.limit.name: entities.limit
entities.limit.description: Maximum number of entities to return.

entities.mentions.name: entities.mentions
entities.mentions.description: Set this to `true` to return locations of entity mentions

entities.model.name: entities.model
entities.model.description: Enter a [custom model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing) ID to override the standard entity detection model

entities.emotion.name: entities.emotion
entities.emotion.description: Set this to `true` to return emotion information for detected entities

entities.sentiment.name: entities.sentiment
entities.sentiment.description: Set this to `true` to return sentiment information for detected entities

keywords.emotion.name: keywords.emotion
keywords.emotion.description: Set this to `true` to return emotion information for detected keywords

keywords.limit.name: keywords.limit
keywords.limit.description: Maximum number of keywords to return.

keywords.sentiment.name: keywords.sentiment
keywords.sentiment.description: Set this to `true` to return sentiment information for detected keywords

relations.model.name: relations.model
relations.model.description: Enter a [custom model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing) ID to override the default `en-news` relations model

semantic_roles.limit.name: semantic_roles.limit
semantic_roles.limit.description: Maximum number of semantic_roles results to return

semantic_roles.entities.name: semantic_roles.entities
semantic_roles.entities.description: Set this to `true` to return entity information for subjects and objects

semantic_roles.keywords.name: semantic_roles.keywords
semantic_roles.keywords.description: Set this to `true` to return keyword information for subjects and objects

sentiment.document.name: sentiment.document
sentiment.document.description: Set this to `false` to disable document level sentiment analysis

sentiment.targets.name: sentiment.targets
sentiment.targets.description: Sentiment information will return for each target string that is found in the text

sentiment.model.name: sentiment.model
sentiment.model.description: (Beta) Enter a [custom model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing) ID to override the standard sentiment model for all sentiment analysis operations in the request, including targeted sentiment for entities and keywords.

syntax.tokens.name: syntax.tokens
syntax.tokens.description: Set this to `true` to return information about the tokens in the input text.

syntax.tokens.lemma.name: syntax.tokens.lemma
syntax.tokens.lemma.description: Set this to `true` to return the lemma for each token.

syntax.tokens.part_of_speech.name: syntax.tokens.part_of_speech
syntax.tokens.part_of_speech.description: Set this to `true` to return the part of speech for each token.

syntax.sentences.name: syntax.sentences
syntax.sentences.description: Set this to `true` to return information about the sentences in the input text.

allOf.description:
The advanced rules feature is deprecated. Existing models are supported until 24 June 2021, but after 10 June 2021, you will not be able to deploy advanced rules models to Natural Language Understanding. After 24 June 2021, advanced rules models will not run in Natural Language Understanding.

Advanced rules model

features.description: The service features that are supported by the custom model

status.description: When the status is `available`, the model is ready to use

workspace_id.description: ID of the Watson Knowledge Studio workspace that deployed this model to Natural Language Understanding

created.description: dateTime indicating when the model was created

example.message: Training data validation failed: Too few examples for label insufficient_examples. Minimum of 5 required
Not enough examples for class 'foo'. 4 were given but 5 are required.

last_trained.description: dateTime of last successful model training

last_deployed.description: dateTime of last successful model deployment

AdvancedRulesModelList.description:
The advanced rules feature is deprecated. Existing models are supported until 24 June 2021, but after 10 June 2021, you will not be able to deploy advanced rules models to Natural Language Understanding. After 24 June 2021, advanced rules models will not run in Natural Language Understanding.

List of advanced rules models.

model.description:
The advanced rules feature is deprecated. Existing models are supported until 24 June 2021, but after 10 June 2021, you will not be able to deploy advanced rules models to Natural Language Understanding. After 24 June 2021, advanced rules models will not run in Natural Language Understanding.

Model file exported from the advanced rules editor in Watson Knowledge Studio. For more information, see [Creating an advanced rules model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/watson-knowledge-studio?topic=watson-knowledge-studio-create-advanced-rules-model#create-advanced-rules-model-procedure).

text.description: The plain text to analyze. One of the `text`, `html`, or `url` parameters is required.

html.description: The HTML file to analyze. One of the `text`, `html`, or `url` parameters is required.

url.description: The webpage to analyze. One of the `text`, `html`, or `url` parameters is required.

allOf.description: Specific features to analyze the document for

clean.description: Set this to `false` to disable webpage cleaning. For more information about webpage cleaning, see [Analyzing webpages](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-analyzing-webpages).

xpath.description: An [XPath query](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-analyzing-webpages#xpath) to perform on `html` or `url` input. Results of the query will be appended to the cleaned webpage text before it is analyzed. To analyze only the results of the XPath query, set the `clean` parameter to `false`.

fallback_to_raw.description: Whether to use raw HTML content if text cleaning fails

return_analyzed_text.description: Whether or not to return the analyzed text

language.description: ISO 639-1 code that specifies the language of your text. This overrides automatic language detection. Language support differs depending on the features you include in your analysis. For more information, see [Language support](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-language-support).

limit_text_characters.description: Sets the maximum number of characters that are processed by the service.

advanced_rules.model.description:
The advanced rules feature is deprecated. Existing models are supported until 24 June 2021, but after 10 June 2021, you will not be able to deploy advanced rules models to Natural Language Understanding. After 24 June 2021, advanced rules models will not run in Natural Language Understanding.

An advanced rules model ID

ListModelsResults.description: Custom models that are available for entities and relations

features.description: The service features that are supported by the custom model

status.description: When the status is `available`, the model is ready to use

created.description: dateTime indicating when the model was created

last_trained.description: dateTime of last successful model training

last_deployed.description: dateTime of last successful model deployment

user_metadata.description: An optional map of metadata key-value pairs to store with this model

language.description: The 2-letter language code of this model

description.description: An optional description of the model

example.message: Training data validation failed: Too few examples for label insufficient_examples. Minimum of 5 required
Not enough examples for class 'foo'. 4 were given but 5 are required.

workspace_id.description: ID of the Watson Knowledge Studio workspace that deployed this model to Natural Language Understanding

status.description: When the status is `available`, the model is ready to use

language.description: ISO 639-1 code that indicates the language of the model

workspace_id.description: ID of the Watson Knowledge Studio workspace that deployed this model to Natural Language Understanding

model_version.description: The model version, if it was manually provided in Watson Knowledge Studio

version_description.description: The description of the version, if it was manually provided in Watson Knowledge Studio

created.description: A dateTime indicating when the model was created

training_data.description: Training data in CSV format. For more information, see [Sentiment training data requirements](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-custom-sentiment#sentiment-training-data-requirements).

ModelMetadata.description: Metadata associated with this custom model

name.description: An optional name for the model

user_metadata.description: An optional map of metadata key-value pairs to store with this model

language.description: The 2-letter language code of this model

description.description: An optional description of the model

workspace_id.description: ID of the Watson Knowledge Studio workspace that deployed this model to Natural Language Understanding

AnalysisResults.description: Results of the analysis, organized by feature

language.description: Language used to analyze the text

analyzed_text.description: Text that was used in the analysis

retrieved_url.description: URL of the webpage that was analyzed

allOf.description: API usage information for the request

advanced_rules.description:
The advanced rules feature is deprecated. Existing models are supported until 24 June 2021, but after 10 June 2021, you will not be able to deploy advanced rules models to Natural Language Understanding. After 24 June 2021, advanced rules models will not run in Natural Language Understanding.

Response from advanced rules analysis

additionalProperties.description: The keys and values from the text extractor in the exported model file from Watson Knowledge Studio. For more information about the format, see [Output format for advanced rules analysis](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing#advanced-rules-analysis-output).

features.description: Number of features used in the API call

Notice.description: A list of messages describing model training issues when model status is `error`

message.description: Describes deficiencies or inconsistencies in training data

FeaturesResults.description: Analysis results for each requested feature

concepts.description: The general concepts referenced or alluded to in the analyzed text

entities.description: The entities detected in the analyzed text

keywords.description: The keywords from the analyzed text

categories.description: The categories that the service assigned to the analyzed text.

classifications.description: The classifications assigned to the analyzed text.

allOf.description: The anger, disgust, fear, joy, or sadness conveyed by the content
Webpage metadata, such as the author and the title of the page

relations.description: The relationships between entities in the content

example.sentence: Leonardo DiCaprio won Best Actor in a Leading Role for his performance.
IBM has one of the largest workforces in the world

object.text: one of the largest workforces in the world

allOf.description: The sentiment of the content

ConceptsResult.description: The general concepts referenced or alluded to in the analyzed text

relevance.description: Relevance score between 0 and 1. Higher scores indicate greater relevance

allOf.description: Link to the corresponding DBpedia resource

DBpediaResource.description: Link to the corresponding DBpedia resource

allOf.description: Link to the corresponding DBpedia resource

EntitiesResult.description: The important people, places, geopolitical entities and other types of entities in your content

relevance.description: Relevance score from 0 to 1. Higher values indicate greater relevance

confidence.description: Confidence in the entity identification from 0 to 1. Higher values indicate higher confidence. In standard entities requests, confidence is returned only for English text. All entities requests that use custom models return the confidence score.

count.description: How many times the entity was mentioned in the text

allOf.description: Emotion analysis results for the entity, enabled with the `emotion` option
Sentiment analysis results for the entity, enabled with the `sentiment` option
Disambiguation information for the entity

location.description: Character offsets indicating the beginning and end of the mention in the analyzed text

confidence.description: Confidence in the entity identification from 0 to 1. Higher values indicate higher confidence. In standard entities requests, confidence is returned only for English text. All entities requests that use custom models return the confidence score.

KeywordsResult.description: The important keywords in the content, organized by relevance

count.description: Number of times the keyword appears in the analyzed text

relevance.description: Relevance score from 0 to 1. Higher values indicate greater relevance

allOf.description: Emotion analysis results for the keyword, enabled with the `emotion` option
Sentiment analysis results for the keyword, enabled with the `sentiment` option

CategoriesResult.description: A categorization of the analyzed text

label.description: The path to the category through the multi-level taxonomy hierarchy. For more information about the categories, see [Categories hierarchy](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-categories#categories-hierarchy).

score.description: Confidence score for the category classification. Higher values indicate greater confidence.

explanation.description: Information that helps to explain what contributed to the categories result.

relevant_text.description: An array of relevant text from the source that contributed to the categorization. The sorted array begins with the phrase that contributed most significantly to the result, followed by phrases that were less and less impactful.

CategoriesRelevantText.description: Relevant text that contributed to the categorization.

text.description: Text from the analyzed source that supports the categorization.

ClassificationsResult.description: A classification of the analyzed text

confidence.description: Confidence score for the classification. Higher values indicate greater confidence.

EmotionResult.description: The detected anger, disgust, fear, joy, or sadness that is conveyed by the content. Emotion information can be returned for detected entities, keywords, or user-specified target phrases found in the text

allOf.description: Emotion results for the document as a whole

DocumentEmotionResults.description: Emotion results for the document as a whole

allOf.description: Emotion results for the document as a whole

TargetedEmotionResults.description: Emotion results for a specified target

allOf.description: The emotion results for the target

anger.description: Anger score from 0 to 1. A higher score means that the text is more likely to convey anger

disgust.description: Disgust score from 0 to 1. A higher score means that the text is more likely to convey disgust

fear.description: Fear score from 0 to 1. A higher score means that the text is more likely to convey fear

joy.description: Joy score from 0 to 1. A higher score means that the text is more likely to convey joy

sadness.description: Sadness score from 0 to 1. A higher score means that the text is more likely to convey sadness

MetadataResult.description: The authors, publication date, title, prominent page image, and RSS/ATOM feeds of the webpage. Supports URL and HTML input types

publication_date.description: The publication date in the format ISO 8601

image.description: URL of a prominent image on the webpage

feeds.description: RSS/ATOM feeds found on the webpage

Author.description: The author of the analyzed content

Feed.description: RSS or ATOM feed found on the webpage

link.description: URL of the RSS or ATOM feed

RelationsResult.description: The relations between entities found in the content

score.description: Confidence score for the relation. Higher values indicate greater confidence.

sentence.description: The sentence that contains the relation

arguments.description: Entity mentions that are involved in the relation

location.description: Character offsets indicating the beginning and end of the mention in the analyzed text

text.description: Text that corresponds to the argument

RelationEntity.description: An entity that corresponds with an argument in a relation

text.description: Text that corresponds to the entity

SemanticRolesResult.description: The object containing the actions and the objects the actions act upon

sentence.description: Sentence from the source that contains the subject, action, and object

allOf.description: The extracted subject from the sentence
The extracted action from the sentence
The extracted object from the sentence

text.description: Text that corresponds to the subject role
Analyzed text that corresponds to the action

allOf.description: The document level sentiment

label.description: Indicates whether the sentiment is positive, neutral, or negative

SyntaxResult.description: Tokens and sentences returned from syntax analysis.

example.text: Today, IBM and Workday, a leading provider of enterprise applications for human resources and finance, announced a joint solution designed to help companies begin the process of safely re-opening their workplaces. Here are five key takeaways from the announcement. The two companies, which have had a partnership since 2011, announced a new solution to help businesses and communities determine when and how to safely open up their workplaces during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

text.description: The token as it appears in the analyzed text.

part_of_speech.description: The part of speech of the token. For more information about the values, see [Universal Dependencies POS tags](https://universaldependencies.org/u/pos/).

location.description: Character offsets indicating the beginning and end of the token in the analyzed text.
Character offsets indicating the beginning and end of the sentence in the analyzed text.

ConceptsOptions.description:
Returns high-level concepts in the content. For example, a research paper about deep learning might return the concept, "Artificial Intelligence" although the term is not mentioned.

Supported languages: English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, Spanish.

limit.description: Maximum number of concepts to return.

EmotionOptions.description:
Detects anger, disgust, fear, joy, or sadness that is conveyed in the content or by the context around target phrases specified in the targets parameter. You can analyze emotion for detected entities with `entities.emotion` and for keywords with `keywords.emotion`.

Supported languages: English

document.description: Set this to `false` to hide document-level emotion results

targets.description: Emotion results will be returned for each target string that is found in the document

EntitiesOptions.description:
Identifies people, cities, organizations, and other entities in the content. For more information, see [Entity types and subtypes](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-entity-type-systems).

Supported languages: English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Swedish. Arabic, Chinese, and Dutch are supported only through custom models.

limit.description: Maximum number of entities to return.

mentions.description: Set this to `true` to return locations of entity mentions

model.description: Enter a [custom model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing) ID to override the standard entity detection model

sentiment.description: Set this to `true` to return sentiment information for detected entities

emotion.description: Set this to `true` to analyze emotion for detected keywords

KeywordsOptions.description:
Returns important keywords in the content.

Supported languages: English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Swedish.

limit.description: Maximum number of keywords to return

sentiment.description: Set this to `true` to return sentiment information for detected keywords

emotion.description: Set this to `true` to analyze emotion for detected keywords

MetadataOptions.description: Returns information from the document, including author name, title, RSS/ATOM feeds, prominent page image, and publication date. Supports URL and HTML input types only.

RelationsOptions.description:
Recognizes when two entities are related and identifies the type of relation. For example, an `awardedTo` relation might connect the entities "Nobel Prize" and "Albert Einstein". For more information, see [Relation types](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-relations).

Supported languages: Arabic, English, German, Japanese, Korean, Spanish. Chinese, Dutch, French, Italian, and Portuguese custom models are also supported.

model.description: Enter a [custom model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing) ID to override the default model

SemanticRolesOptions.description:
Parses sentences into subject, action, and object form.

Supported languages: English, German, Japanese, Korean, Spanish.

limit.description: Maximum number of semantic_roles results to return

keywords.description: Set this to `true` to return keyword information for subjects and objects

entities.description: Set this to `true` to return entity information for subjects and objects

SentimentOptions.description:
Analyzes the general sentiment of your content or the sentiment toward specific target phrases. You can analyze sentiment for detected entities with `entities.sentiment` and for keywords with `keywords.sentiment`.

 Supported languages: Arabic, English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish

document.description: Set this to `false` to hide document-level sentiment results

targets.description: Sentiment results will be returned for each target string that is found in the document

training_data.description: Training data in JSON format. For more information, see [Categories training data requirements](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-categories##categories-training-data-requirements).

CategoriesOptions.description:
Returns a hierarchical taxonomy of the content. The top three categories are returned by default. 

Supported languages: Arabic, English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, Spanish.

explanation.description: Set this to `true` to return explanations for each categorization. **This is available only for English categories.**

limit.description: Maximum number of categories to return.

model.description: (Beta) Enter a [custom model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing) ID to override the standard categories model. **This is available only for English categories.**

training_data.description: Training data in JSON format. For more information, see [Classifications training data requirements](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-classifications#classification-training-data-requirements).

ClassificationsOptions.description: Returns text classifications for the content.

model.description:
Enter a [custom model](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-customizing) ID of the classifications model to be used. 

You can analyze tone by using a language-specific model ID. See [Tone analytics (Classifications)](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-tone_analytics) for more information.

SummarizationOptions.description:
(Experimental) Returns a summary of content. 

Supported languages: English only. 

Supported regions: Dallas region only

limit.description: Maximum number of summary sentences to return

SyntaxOptions.description: Returns tokens and sentences from the input text.

lemma.description: Set this to `true` to return the lemma for each token.

part_of_speech.description: Set this to `true` to return the part of speech for each token.

sentences.description: Set this to `true` to return sentence information.

ClassificationsTrainingParameters.description: Optional classifications training parameters along with model train requests

model_type.description: Model type selector to train either a single_label or a multi_label classifier
